5701.title: The Gates of Castle Balkra
5701.description:
A stone road leads to the massive structure of Castle Balkra. The gigantic
iron gates which lock the outer keep are swung wide open.  The hardened stone
walls of the castle loom about three to four stories. Battle runes and mottos
are inscribed within the front stone walls. From this spot four large towers
can be seen jutting out of the four corners of the castle.  On each tower a
Crusader banner whips in the winds. The stone blocks forming the thick
structure of the outer castle gleam white in either sunlight or moonlight. If
you're an intruder your awakening is a rude one if the Samurai guardian is
present to deliver a devastating assault.

5702.title: The Halls of Memory
5702.description:
You stand in a grand open space just inside the keep of the castle.  The
ceiling arches overhead, forming a large dome of stone which travels a long
ways into the Keep. The walls and the floors are cut from the finest grade of
stone. The placement of each stone is with near perfection, impressing anyone
with the knowledge of architecture. Numerous pictures of famed battles
entirely cover the walls and ceilings, and famous Crusader legends adorn the
hall in the form of lifelike marble statues. The glory of the past thrives
with life as one walks the halls of memories.

extras.description:
A Brief Explanation of the Ages as Reckoned by the Steel Clan:
The First Age refers to the first recorded age of the history of the
illustrious Steel Clan. This was a time when the Clan was known as The
Crusaders of Valor, a name they still proudly bear. The First Age began with
the leadership of Rengar, while Aegnor still watched over the Keep from the
Heavens. The Keep was located in the midst of Castle Valor in those days. Two
events brought about the end of the First Age: The defeat and destruction of
the Keep by Prince Styx and the Enforcers taking advantage of the Crusaders'
weakness after a rough series of battles in their war against the ArchMages of
Arcana, and the unexplained disappearance of Lord Aegnor. The last recorded
leader of the First Age was Racquel, a fierce female who led the Steel Clan to
a number of victories as it grew from the rubble of the First Age, having
relocated to a Keep built behind the house of the Crusader, Druvka.
The end of the First Age and the beginning of the Second Age were a little
blurred in history. As Racquel is considered the last leader of the First Age,
Ripsaw is considered the first leader of the Second Age. At this time, The
Crusaders of Valor began to call themselves the Steel Clan. Lord Julive oversaw
the House, wresting it from Lord Ceran, who had interfered with and taken over
the House toward the last days of Lord Aegnor's leadership from the Heavens.
This Heavenly struggle had begun toward the end of the First Age and roughly
produced the Second Age. The Second Age lasted a very long time, during which
many notable and valiant Crusaders lived and died, and a couple ascended to the
Heavens (Darkwood and Gryleth). The gods continued to strive, and with the
disappearance of Lord Julive came the rising of a great and powerful Maelstrom
who oversaw the House. It was during this time that the Tower of Arcana in the
Icy Wastes was laid waste, giving rise to the underwater Library Tower of
Arcana. When Lord Maelstrom interfered with the strong magic within the Library
Tower, Lady Xyza came to the Keep in Rockfist and reversed the power of the
anti-magic which Lord Julive had set in place within the Keep. Not long after,
Lords Darkwood and Gryleth led an all-out assault upon the Library Tower of
Arcana, tearing it apart and crushing the Crystal of Power, sending magic into
chaos and showing the weakness of the Weave which Lord Maelstrom had predicted
would be evident.
With the destruction of the Library Tower of Arcana came the end of the valiant
Second Age and the beginning of the Third Age, a time of reflection and
reconsideration of how to continue the holy war against mortal magic.  The
Steel Clan found itself at war with a growing dark Empire, although the
emphasis had been on targeting powerful mages wherever they could be found.
This was also a time of rebuilding and renewal, rising up from old wounds.  The
Keep at Rockfist was a ruin, and the Steel Clan hired dwarves and giants to
fashion a new place. The new Keep was a castle in and of itself, named by Lord
Darkwood as Castle Balkra, located on property claimed by the minotaurs of
Mahn-Tor Keep. This resulted in some trouble between the Crusaders and the
Mahn-Torean warriors who clashed from time to time as the minotaurs tried to
stop or destroy the new castle. Lord Jord Roshnak was the last leader of the
Steel Clan to face the minotaurean hordes in their efforts to destroy Castle
Balkra. Although there were no great battles with master mages of such power as
the ArchMages of Arcana, a number of great heroes lived during this time, most
notably the trollkin Warlord named Moloch, who reacted to the edicts of Lord
Hector of the Empire of Legion by proudly calling himself a Dirt Farmer (for in
those days, Lord Hector had announced that the larger races, the trolls,
giants, and centaurs, were unfit to take on the mantle of leadership and were
no better than dirt farmers). Warlord Moloch plowed a great number of 'smart
mages' into the dirt during the Third Age.
The Third Age passed into the Fourth Age during a time of politcal upheaval.
Its roots were both within the magic guild of Channelers, whose masters began
teaching specializations within the guild, and within the blood of Lord
Darkwood himself. The Guardian of Honor had begun a program of purifying mages.
An arborian by the name of Cahaba was the first mage to give up his magic and
become purified of the tainted power. Soon after his purification, he
disappeared. The second mage to be purified was Princess Joja of Dhaes Drae
Aesilon. On the night of her rebirth, the Empire lost its Empress Yukino in a
struggle to the death in the very place that the former mage was reborn into
purity. During the last week of Jord's mortal life on Thera, Joja was brought
into Castle Balkra to begin her training as a Warrior of Steel. But her best
weapon was her wit and her ability to communicate with mages on their level of
understanding. After centuries of bloodshed to defeat magic, she tried a
totally different tactic, reasoning with them.  The results were devasating to
the magic community as many mages either gave up magic entirely, or took their
own lives. Lord Nixalis was the first leader of the Fourth Age. With Joja as
Envoy, and the mighty centaur Bradwarden as Warlord, they led the Steel Clan to
amazing victories against mortal magic. The Steel Clan won a resounding victory
against the Enforcers of the Law, who had declared war upon Balkra. It was
during this time also that the first Hellhole opened and the demonsummoners who
called themsevles Brethren of the Nine Hells rose up to power, easily
targetting Castle Balkra as the home of their greatest enemy, although the
warriors of the Tree of Life were also a power for them to reckon with. Indeed,
the Steel Clan seemed destined to fall in the midst of its greatest moment in
history, when mages were dying fast. Through the hardships, the leaders of the
Steel perservered, and the dark Brethren diminished in number, their power
waning, their dark gods abandoning them.  As the evil powers waned, a new
magical power arose, at first near the Castle Balkra, and then magically moving
their Hourglass Tower to a position of obscurity south of Arkham. The Conclave
of Wizards was the result of the studies of Lord Riallus WindGust, the
MageLord, who sought to bring back the glory of Arcana of old with the new
thinking of research and understanding of magic. Lord Darkwood trained Lady
Joja to oversee the Steel Clan, and with a number of others aiding her, the
Clan has risen from its reputation as a House of overmuscled dullards to a
House of honorable warriors with sharp wit.
Here we stand today, in the Fourth Age. Empires have risen and fallen, the
darkest evil rose from the depths of the Abyss and fell back again. The Age of
Reason remains with us, we who are not only renowned for our physical strength,
but also for our mental power to understand right from wrong, and to teach the
people of Thera so that the weakened Weave may strengthen and remain strong,
and the natural world of Thera may remain healthy and beautiful as it was meant
to be. The challenge is no less today than it was in what many call the Golden
Age. It is, in fact, a greater challenge, as the foolish arrogance of mages
rises up against the tide of Steel. Our march to victory continues.

5703.title: The Halls of Memory
5703.description:
Any sound created in this hall echoes down the large stretch of the stone
domed ceiling. The finely polished stones that make up the walls and floor
are scattered with works of art. Paintings display the tales of Crusader
immortals. Scenes of great battles between the Crusader gods and their divine
enemies jump out in vivid colors and detail. A feeling of awesome power
entirely foreign to mortal experience surges though many of the works of art.
Large marble statues representing the titans themselves line the long stone
hall. The mere act of traveling past the statues evokes an overwhelming sense
of awe. On the walls near the Inner Keep you see a number of haphazardly
spaced human handprints in dried blood.

5704.title: The Inner Keep
5704.description:
This is the heart of the Castle Balkra. The massive stone ceiling of the
inner keep arches overhead. Oversized Roman arches are formed from large
granite stones, allowing entrance or exit in all the cardinal directions.
Suits of various armors decorate this well traveled hall at various spots.
The grey stone floor is polished to a near mirror shine. Along the floor
toward the west, running north and south along the walls in the passages to
the north and south, is a marble pipe. The walls are covered with dried
blood in the shape of human hand prints haphazardly spaced, some overlapping.

5705.title: The Hall of History
5705.description:
As you enter the hall of history you are forced to sneeze from the dust
gathered about. Shelves, cases, storage bins, and racks of every sort litter
the room. Relics, ancient weapons, shields, figurines, old maps, cloaks,
armor, anything old that relates to war or Crusader history seems to be
collected here.  Brass, steel, iron, stone, different woods, gems, myriad
piles of material glimmer in the light. Layers of dust pile on many of the
items. You wonder how many treasures are hidden about in this room.

5706.title: Further in the Keep
5706.description:
This hall carries you further ino Castle Balkra. Each step sounds off a deep
echo carried through the heavy stone halls. To the east under a large Roman
arch lies a large barracks. To the north one can make their way further to
the east side of the castle. Along the base of the wall to the west, there is
a marble pipe stretching toward the north and south. Both east and west walls
near the Inner Keep are covered with haphazardly spaced human hand prints in
dried blood.
A proclamation entitled WAR AGREEMENT hangs on the eastern wall.

extras.description:
WAR AGREEMENT
To: Crusader and  Conclave:
The below outlines the agreement between Crusader and Conclave as
it pertains to raids and the war period between the two great Houses:
There shall be no raids unless a mortal defender capable of fighting is
within the realms.  This defender needs not be at the Guardian, merely
in the lands.  In respect to conclave apprentices - it is their duty to
expect such a raid when a crusader is present.  The Crusader may
notify the apprentice, but is not required to do so.
Exception to above - it is permissible to raid without mortal defender
to balance the power advantage.  To win by Absence is not an honorable
or acceptable war strategy.
Duels can be offered and should be offered.  If they are refused then
either side may regain their respective artifact by attack and raid.
if a raid is started while a mortal defender is in the lands and said
defender departs the raid is to be completed and the item of power
may be taken.
During the war period only to ensure these terms are being met when
there is a raid a scroll is to be sent to EACH house stating who attacked
and who was in the realms to defend.
The above is the official agreement as prepared by Wojciecha of House
Crusader and Quenton of House Conclave.
Sealed:
Wojciecha, Leader of the Neverending Crusader
Quenton, Master of the Tower
1st the Month of the Winter Wolf, Year 215
Amendment
To: Crusader and Conclave
The treaty is once again back in place between our houses. There are
amendments to adress and so we do so now. There will be NO defenderless
raids on the houses. This will make the battles in the weeks between
the times of combat worth gaining. Gain the advantage during the week
could decide the result of the entire war.
To revisit the subject, there is no longer the possibility regaining
advantage by raiding without a defender in place.
Signed:
Segovax Raw, Leader of the Crusades
Quenton Beck, Master of the Tower
5th the Month of the Battle, Year 223

5707.title: East side of the Keep
5707.description:
This is the far eastern side of the keep. As with the rest of Castle Balkra,
the craftsmanship of stone here is the finest in the land. Torches hung to
the solid stone walls cast a creepy shadow as you make your way through this
room. The stone keep seems to offer little comfort as a chill of cool air
blows through the hall. To the west, east, and south a large Roman arch leads
to other parts of the castle. Along the floor to the west, a marble pipe runs
north and south, and at the northern wall turns toward the east, running
along the base of the wall.

5708.title: The Altar of The Never Ending Crusades
5708.description:
You stand in the most sacred room in Castle Balkra. High above polished granite
walls is a nice vaulted ceiling, a dome covered with a mosaic of brilliant
colors depicting the life of the First Crusader, a dwarf who gave his life
and soul to be housed in the Gauntlet. The walls themselves are so shiny they
appear to glow with a luminescence that seems almost alive. Inscribed on the
north and south walls are different parts of page sixteen of the Crusader Book
of the Code. Covering much of the wall behind the altar is a huge painting
depicting a nature scene. The altar itself is fashioned as a pristine block of
granite sitting upon a base of marble, with circular stairs leading up to it.
Inside the altar lies the War Gauntlet which is guarded day and night by the
Wise One. It is rumored that to touch the Gauntlet of War with an impure
warrior's soul is to incur the wrath of the gods of war. The floor is also of
marble, and it is very clean despite the fact that many booted feet that have
trodden upon mud and dirt must enter here at one time or another.

extras.description:
The painting seems to glow with light and life, and its subject is of nature.
Standing among many berry trees is a huge stag with a ten-point rack. The sun
is out, brightening the day, but also each of the moons is out, and each one
seems to be full: white Lomenthiel, grey Erohach, and amber Gu. All four
celestial orbs are located in the upper left corner of the painting. In the
foreground are three people familiar to the Steel Clan. Standing in the fore
is and holding the steel War Gauntlet is Joja, the winged grey-elven goddess
clothed in the velvets she wore when she married Krazar Lechium, who stands
behind her and, being a huge giant, eclipses many of the trees. Standing next
to Krazar is Darkwood, Guardian of Honor, who, being an even bigger giant,
eclipses most of the rest of the trees. You can tell the difference between
the giants because Darkwood's face is covered by an iron mask with bits of
skin hanging from it. Behind the giants and the berry trees (the ones still
visible), you see a mountain rising. You can tell that it is a mountain
because it is taller than the giants.

You look at the north wall and see neatly inscribed within the polished
illuminated granite wall:
The Ideal Crusader is one who keeps the purity of his soul, of his life,
and of his honor before all else.
The Ideal Crusader gives his life in the name of the Crusades, and sees
only the honor in his actions.
The Ideal Crusader does not need to justify his actions, for they are
without question.
The Ideal Crusader lives a life untainted by mortal magic and dishonor.

You look at the south wall and see neatly inscribed within the polished
illuminated granite wall:
The Ideal Crusader is one who fights with wisdom and bravery at all times.
The Ideal Crusader is one who gives respect to all around him, for he knows
that to give respect is to receive. Earning respect is a myth. To treat one
with disrespect merely because they have given you disrespect is to lower
yourself to their level, and a Crusader is better than that.
The Ideal Crusader is one who has learned that your Life is your Honor.
That Honor goes beyond fighting and dueling. Your honor can be seen in all
that you do and say.
The Ideal Crusader is YOU should you apply yourself. Follow the Code and
keep Honor foremost in your thoughts at all times.

5709.title: The Chamber of Decisions
5709.description:
A huge mass of red oak forms a circle table that takes up half of the room.
Oversized solid oak chairs with tall backs line the edge of the giant table.
One chair dwarfs the rest, its size large enough for a titan to sit in.
Battle maps and charts are pinned to various points of the walls. This seems
to be the room where many of the important decisions take place. Near one of
the many maps on the wall is a framed leather scroll. Below it is a second
framed leather scroll, this one sealed with green and adorned with a green
ribbon. In one corner is a rock bearing the likenesses of a centaur, a dwarf,
and a canine which strongly resembles a wolf. There are small words chiseled
in the bottom corner of the rock.

extras.description:
Korrick, Garkum, and Skean
Day of Moon, 8th the Month of the Heat, Year 181
Performance of A Fairy Tale
Drawn by Garkum

Looking closely at the words, you sense that the hand which scribed them was
divine. You focus upon them and read:
A change will be amended to the Code starting now
This point on, any house which we are at war with, whom raids our castle
with more than one member will be subject to the full fury of our defending
members, target them at will.
Rember, this is only for Houses which we are at war with, only if
they raid our keep with more than one member
(If only one member of the house raids alone, then treat them as normal and
call them)
Looting policy remains the same follow it
Those at war with us will know we will defend our castle at all costs
Envoy please make this policy known to the land
Darkwood, The Guardian of Honor

You see a large leather scroll with a green seal and ribbon. It says:
I decree a new change of policy for House Crusader
Let it be known to all from this day foward that any House at war
with Crusader may be looted to the full extent
This excludes duels of Honor with the enemy, but for battles any
Crusader may fully loot a enemy House member
This does not change our looting policy for those not at war with
us, Honor shall be shown
May Honor guide all,
Darkwood, Nature's Wrath, The Gaurdian of Honor

5710.title: Library of the Crusades
5710.description:
Rows and rows of heavy oak book shelves line this warm room. Books of almost
every size, color, age, and topic considered important to a Crusader fill the
shelves. Numerous scrolls are plastered to the walls, lay sprawed out on
tables, or sticking out of cubby holes. A warm glow emanates from the large
brick fireplace at the north end of the library. Large picture blocks with
the alphabet on them lay in many boxes to aid the needs of the many Crusaders
who are "challenged". You notice a librarian working diligently to keep this
place in order.

extras.description:
A few books catch your eye.  They are titled "Beginning", "Recent History",
"Patience", "Ranks", "Banned", "Battle", and "Ancient History".

The gnome Crusader, Druvka, offered his home to be the location of the new
Crusader Keep.  Combining the efforts of Lord Julive's divine power, and the
few gnomes that were willing to volunteer their services, the new keep was
constructed.

Since time and blood have proven only that magic is a force overwhelming in
its nature, it has been decreed that time and patience shall prove the
Crusade's mightiest ally.  With constant effort and wise leadership, the
Crusade shall grow in strength as Therans realize that magic is a thing best
left in divine hands, and that combat is the purist art form there is. On the
day when all of Thera stands behind the Crusade, then the final points of
resistance shall be swept from Thera in a tide of steel!

The ranking system of the great Army of the Crusade is as follows:
Daggers     - These are the lowest ranks, usually fairly new members.  The
Daggers often run errands for the higher-ranked members of The
Army, and are expected to offer their gear to naked members
that rank above them.
Broadswords - The Broadswords have proven themselves to be valuable members
of The Army through Valorous combat.  Most Crusaders are at
this rank, and they are expected to show unfailing bravery in
the face of any and all danger.
WarHammers  - Those Crusaders who time and time again prove themselves to be
Warriors of a truly exceptional caliber are often granted the
rank of WarHammer.  Much of the burden of raiding and defense
falls to the Warhammers, since they are adept at all manners
and styles of combat.
BattleAxes  - When a Warrior demonstrates prowess above and beyond his peers
in all things desired from a Crusader, he is granted the title
of BattleAxe.  BattleAxes are those who have found true union
with the spirit of battle, and understand the spiritual nature
of the hunt and the fight.
Warlord     - The Warlord of The Army is chosen from the ranks of the Battle-
Axes, and is expected to lead The Army in matters military.  In
matters military, only the Leader can overrule the word of the
Warlord.
Envoy       - The Envoy is the political leader of The Army, and is
responsible for interviewing applicants and negotiating with
members of other Houses.  In matters political, only the Leader
can overrule the word of the Envoy.
Leader      - The Leader is the most elite member of The Army.  Chosen from
either the Warlords or the Envoy, the word of the Leader is law
for the rest of The Army.

A Crusader is an elite warrior and is expected to act with Valor and
Discipline.  Intent and action are judged independently when the Battle Code
is applied, so a Crusader is responsible both for their intent AND the
outcome of their actions.  Ignorance and errors are not acceptable excuses.
Unless stated otherwise, the following rules apply to all situations where a
Crusader anticipates combat with another mortal soul.
BATTLE CODE OF THE CRUSADES
I.    A true Warrior must fight alone.  Do not group with or work with any
other when fighting, whether intentionally or incidentally.  This means
no bouncing a target between attackers.  There is NO excuse for break-
ing this rule.
II.   The resources of the Crusade should focus on those who use sorcerous
magic. We have no desire to alienate those who walk the line, rather we
would see them converted to the ways of purity.
III.  When attacking an enemy, a Crusader is to announce that target over the
House channel, This then means no other Crusader can touch that target
until:
A. The target dies.
B. The Crusader hunting dies, in which case the Crusader who wishes
to attack the killer/target must yell out that target's name and
alert them to vengeance in the name of honor as well as making
the House channel announcement.
C. The Crusader who first called the target announces over the
House channel that they no longer hunt the target and is well
out of the area of the target.  Those that wish to hunt then
announce the name over the House channel.
IV.   A mortal is considered one target. Only one Crusader may attack one
target at a time, no matter the number of pets, slaves, or soldiers
that target controls.  Any Crusader in range may attack those creatures
that follow the target in the interest of evening the odds for the
hunting Crusader as long as they DO NOT interfere with the actual
target.
V.    Under no circumstances should the followers of a Crusader (Ranger pets
or enlisted help) outnumber those of the target at the initiation of a
fight. This applies equally to hunting, raiding, defending, and
duelling.  ANY ABUSE of this privilege will result in harsh punishment
and full revocation of this privilege.
VI.  When The Gauntlet is lost Crusaders are to offer a duel to those who
hold it, if refused they are to retrieve it.
VII. If the item of another house is held within the Keep, a duel offered by
the enemy must be accepted (if fair) for a chance to regain it.  Any
Crusader within the range of the challenging party may be chosen as the
House's champion, it need not be the person asked to duel.
VII. The rare exception that Crusaders can attack one or more mages together
is this: Only when the Gauntlet is lost and a duel not accepted for it.
Then The Crusaders may unite to retrieve it.  After its return no such
ganging is allowed.
IX.  Crusaders may not raid a house unless that house has a member to defend
(the member does not have to be in range, immortals do not count).
Crusaders may also raid if the Gauntlet is missing and believed to be in
another house, if it is not that house is not to be raided further.
X.   Duels are matches or combat between two (2) people. Crusaders may duel
for honor, to test themselves, or to retrieve the Gauntlet. A duel is
supposed to be between two people solely, but a Crusader can agree to
handicap him/herself by allowing the rival to use slaves as help. Also
the duel can be to the death or until one loses the will to go on and
flees. The match can have equipment at stake or be merely for challenge.
Before a duel is fought a Crusader should do two things: Make sure the
terms are clear, and have the opponent give a ready signal. The opponent
is to do likewise. In the event that you duel for a House item, no
trophy is to be taken, the corpse of the loser is to be left untouched,
and fallen weapons not taken. Only the House item is at stake. The House
item is to be handed to the enemy if he/she is victorious, not
sacrificed.
XII. When an opponent falls to a Crusader, no more than 1/2 of his/her
possessions may be taken from his/her corpse.  This is for the total
looting, not just what the Crusader takes.  However, a Crusader can keep
1 piece of equipment as a trophy of victory no matter what. If someone
else loots the corpse, the crusader is to try to post a scroll to the
victim stating who, if he knows, and may only keep 1 piece of equipment,
returning the rest. Magical devices such as potions, staves, wands,
etc., are to be sacrificed to the gods. No Crusader shall loot a wedding
ring/band or a leader weapon or item from anyone, to do so is to bring
shame and the wrath of the gods upon oneself.

5711.title: The Northwest Tower
5711.description:
A howling whistle of wind and the draft of cool air welcomes you as you enter
the northwest tower of the castle. Strong granite stones masoned with excep-
tional skill form the cone that makes up the tower. Tall stairs lead upwards,
each step just below an average human's knee spiral to the top. Along the
tower walls murder holes give a field of observation to that side of the
castle. Green moss grows between the goves of the fine stone. A damp cool
breeze of air blows through the tower.

5712.title: The Top of the Northwest Tower
5712.description:
The cross winds blow you slightly about on top of the tower. From this height
all around the castle can be more than clearly viewed. The tower top is
constructed by smaller cut stones than the rest of the castle. It circles
around with large stones placed to allow an opening for sight and a block to
take cover behind. Green moss grows from the cracks of stone and a mildew
scent is carried in the air.

5713.title: The Northeast Tower
5713.description:
A howling whistle of wind and the draft of cool air welcomes you as you enter
the northeast tower of the castle. Strong granite stones masoned with excep-
tional skill form the cone that makes up the tower. Tall stairs lead upwards,
each step just below an average human's knee spiral to the top, where a bit
of extra stone exists which must be stepped over to fully enter the top tower
room. Along the circular tower wall murder holes give a field of observation
to that side of the castle, but unfortunately, not downward at the country-
side below. There seem to be some small markings on the wall hidden among the
various scratches and chips in the stone. Green moss grows between the goves
of the fine stone. A damp, cool breeze blows through this part of the tower.
Along the base of the northern wall is a marble pipe leading toward the west,
and rising upward and then through a marble box-shaped structure standing
upon a tripod of marble legs. The top of the marble box is an iron grate, and
smoke rises from it. The marble pipe exits out the other side and rises up
the northern wall until it disappears through the ceiling. Another pipe runs
across the ceiling and down the northern wall until it finds one of the
murder holes, at which point it turns outward and stops. Water drips from its
open end to the ground below.

extras.description:
The box is filled with something hot. Rocks? Twigs? You can barely make out
burning embers within, for the marble piping gets in the way of your vision.
Touch the box... ouch! It is hot!

May the future generations serve the clan with the honor I tried to
impart to them, with respect inherent in all they do. I can only
hope that reason can temper the heart of the Warriors of steel, so
that we will never again have our mettle tested in the forge of
hardship.
- Restin Delrist

5714.title: The Top of the Northeast Tower
5714.description:
Two arcing stone walls, one to the north, one to the south, rise up, and to the
east are four, large, polished, marble pillars coming up from the ground
outside the Keep, all the way to the top of the Tower. The western wall is
filled with a large, beautiful blue curtain of sturdy make. The curtain is
bound by large, polished brass rings allowing it to be closed or opened at
will. A huge, glass roof covers the top of the Tower. This beautiful roof is
held on metal hinges on both sides allowing the roof to be retracted open or
closed at will. The glass is perfectly transparent allowing sunlight or
moonlight to find the bottom of the floor with ease. Completely encircling the
perimeter of the tower floor is a layer of stone, seemingly a second layer to
what was once the first (wall) layer, and high enough to require that you step
over and onto the tower room floor. That floor is covered with moist soil,
thick in mulch, mixed with decaying leaves, through which many plants have
sprouted. The trees which grow here are twisted and bent. Parts of them look
dead, but new growth has sprouted, and the leaves are a healthy green. Some
of the shrubs have also taken a beating, it appears, but they, too, have new
greenery to show for their fight against the elements. Near the twisted trees,
in the center of the soil-filled floor, off to the side of the worn path, is a
construction known as a dakota hole. At the base of the northern wall and the
secondary inner wall, a marble pipe emerges upward, and warm water trickles out
and soaks the ever moist, mulchy soil. The northern wall appears is perfect
shape, even polished of any dirt or blemishes. On the right side of the
northern wall there is a remaining tree leaning heavily against the top of the
wall, its purchase on the shallow floor iffy. The southern wall has small ivy
vines holding grip to the small grooves in the wall, their tiny green leaves
seeking sunlight. A small grouping of pink roses appears to have taken root
near one of the green shrubs. Near another green shrub a small grouping of
yellow tulips grows. A small white lily grows near the base of one of the
smaller trees. A huge grouping of bright orange and yellow flowers grows in
the eastern section among a few small green shrubs. A small sprig of purple
violets grows outside an overturned box and between two green shrubs.

extras.description:
In the center of the soil-filled floor, you see a round pit which measures
about three feet in depth, and three feet in diameter. This pit is lined
with white quartz, inlaid stones with crushed quartz between. The wind
whips at a number of little pebbles which have found their way to the
bottom of the pit, inspiring them to dance. A tunnel measuring four feet
in length connects this pit to a similar pit, to the south of it, lined
with black onyx, inlaid stones with crushed black onyx between. A few
stray pebbles sit at the bottom of this pit as well.

The north wall is jagged on either side. It has a slightly concave arc to it.
The mortar between the stones which comprise this wall is dry and clean
looking. A slender window breaks the continuity of the stone. Near the
window, a long silver rod hangs across the wall, holding a tapestry.

The tapestry on the long rod appears to be a portrait, perhaps from dictation
and memory, of a number of Clansmen who lived and were active during one of
the Steel Clan's transitory times. Standing in the front is a slight grey-
elven monk who is obviously the Leader. He wears a couple of lapis necklaces
around his neck, and on each wrist a lapis bracelet. His black belt is
decorated with a golden asp. Beside him to the right is a huge centaur, red
haired, with a chestnut coat covering his horse half. His human half seems
soiled with dirt, as of a man not given to dainty passtimes, and he is well
armed. To the Leader's left is a taller grey-elven wearing leather armor. She
holds a long staff in each hand. Long dark hair streaked with red seems to
blow in a breeze. Behind her stand two heavily armored trolls, one in steel
and the other in leather, one holding an axe and the other a large knife.
Both trolls are green skinned, but one has red eyes and hair, the other
yellow eyes and black hair. Behind the centaur, a couple of draconians with
huge bat-like wings stand. Between the two draconians and the two trolls, two
humans, monks like the Leader, stand, somewhat behind him. Both of them wear
black belts, though closer inspection shows both of them to be wearing a
praying mantis upon each one. Sitting on the ground in front are another
human monk, his black belt showing him to be a member of the School of the
Crane, and the other of the School of the Tiger. The Tiger monk wears his
hair in a bowl-shaped hair cut, the rest have short-cropped hair, and the
Crane monk has a bit of fuzz for hair.
Below the tapestry are embroidered names, easy enough to read if you can
read, and if you look hard enough, for the threads blend into the tapestry:
Leader: Nixalis n'Gorlas, Black Belt of the Snake; Warlord: Bradwarden
Varkinlas, Warrior; Envoy: Joja of Dhaes Drae Aesilon, Beast Master. Behind
Envoy: Kalkun Krull, troll barbarian, future Warlord; Bludgwuar Stregheria,
troll hunter, future BattleAxe and BloodKnight. Behind Warlord: Jedke,
draconian warrior, future Warlord; Domenique (sp?), draconian warrior. Behind
Leader: Dhealiminisu, Guildmaster of the Praying Mantis; Lellyn, Black Belt
of the Praying Mantis, future Battleaxe and BloodKnight. Sitting: 'Doc'
Monkifer, Black Belt of the Crane, Battleaxe and Clan physician; Tanzer
Scythe, Black Belt of the Tiger, future BattleAxe.

The south wall slightly arcs concavely, its tightly fit stones held together
by dry, clean mortar. A slender window remains, where once archers could let
fly an arrow at an enemy. Near the window is a silver plaque. Below the
silver plaque is a framed parchment.

The frame is of a finely polished wood, its grain visible through the
contrast of its rings. Upon the flattened parchment is a twin haiku.

Written in a very neat hand, you see the following words:
Purity of self
The harmony of balance
Living as nature
The spirit unbound
Integrity in action
The tao of life's truth
-- Tymoran

5715.title: A large Crusader Barracks
5715.description:
You enter a large Crusader barracks. Oversized cots, bunks, and storage
trunks line the walls. All look large enough to be comfortable to the larger
races. Any Troll, Giant, or Minotaur would find the size of things
compatable. To the north side of the barracks stalls have been constructed
with hay for the centaur race's needs. A large fireplace to the east radiates
heat enough to warm the whole barracks.

5716.title: Further into the Keep
5716.description:
This passage leads further into the keep. Solid stones make up the sturdy
walls of the keep. The floors are polished to a glossy shine. To the east a
Roman arch allows passage to a barracks. To the south you see a lot of
foliage from under the stone arch. Along the base of the wall to the west, a
marble pipe runs north and south. On the walls near the Inner Keep, a number
of human handprints have haphazardly stained the walls with dried blood.

5717.title: A moderate Crusader barracks
5717.description:
You enter a barracks built for the medium and smaller races in the Crusader
ranks. Comfortable cots and bunks with heavy cotton blankets line the walls.
Several nests made of straw and twigs line the northern part of the walls for
the draconian race to sleep in. A fireplace to the east burns various pine
woods, warming the room and carrying the fresh scent of pine in the air.

5718.title: The Green Room
5718.description:
A cool mist and the sound of splashing water greets you as you enter this
part of the keep. It seems the Crusaders planted a miniature forest inside
their castle! For a moment it is hard to tell whether you stand inside or out
until you catch sight of the large stone ceiling arching overhead. Small
oaks, pines, vines, bushes, and flowers of all sorts thrive here. A marble
fountain squirts cool water in the center of the tranquil room. Suddenly, you
notice a figure blended in with the natural colors, eyeing your every move.
Near one of the bushes is a mound and a marker.

extras.description:
The fountain is constructed entirely of marble, and whatever mechanism causes
it to spray water upward and into its pool is unseen. At its base a pipe made
of the same marble emerges from the northern side and continues to run north-
ward through the miniature forest to the center of the keep.

5719.title: The Southeast Tower
5719.description:
A howling whistle of wind and the draft of cool air welcomes you as you enter
the southeast tower of the castle. Strong granite stones masoned with excep-
tional skill form the cone that makes up the tower. Tall stairs lead upwards,
each step just below an average human's knee spiral to the top. Along the
tower walls murder holes give a field of observation to that side of the
castle. Green moss grows between the goves of the fine stone. A damp cool
breeze of air blows through the tower.

5720.title: The Top of the Southeast Tower
5720.description:
The cross winds blow you slightly about on top of the tower. From this height
all around the castle can be more than clearly viewed. The tower top is
constructed by smaller cut stones than the rest of the castle. It circles
around with large stones placed to allow an opening for sight and a block to
take cover behind. Green moss grows from the cracks of stone and a mildew
scent is carried in the air.

5721.title: An intersection
5721.description:
You stand on the far west side of the castle. The stone structure offers
little warmth. A cool breeze blows through the halls. This point of the keep
intersects west, north, and east. A stone stairway also decends in the
southern section of the hall.

5722.title: The Battle Room
5722.description:
This is what is known as the battle room. A rack filled with wooden practice
weapons greets you as you enter. A circular open pit forms a battle arena in
which the monk and gladiator instruct from. Stains of sweat and dried blood
lay scattered about the pit and the heavy scent of salt hang in the air.
Battle charts and graphs of weak points of different races line the walls.
Dummies, many which seem beaten to a pulp, already lie scattered about. This
seems to be the perfect place for a warrior to build and tone the skills of
combat.

5723.title: The Crusader Forge
5723.description:
The tremendous heat almost forces you back out of the room. A blinding light
of molten metals being poured into casts forces your eyes to squint. A large
draconian blacksmith and a gnome weaponsmith work this hellish heated forge
in a furious pace. Nearby, a dwarven mastersmith works the bellows and over-
looks the work. The clanging of metalwork rings throughout the keep, and you
see quenching barrels, filled with different liquids lining the side of the
smithy. A heavy metallic scent looms from the various metals being crafted in
the forge. A heat wave shimmers over the room, distorting your sight. The
blast of heat makes you sweat, and you almost feel as if on fire. Many fine
swords, shields, armors, and weapons of every sort crafted here line the
walls. A cast-iron plaque hangs on the wall near the anvil.

extras.description:
To have the blacksmith remove a curse from an item, say
Undo the wretched grip of magics, blacksmith!
To have the blacksmith return something to its original state, say
Make pure this tainted gear, blacksmith!

5724.title: The Southwest Tower
5724.description:
A howling whistle of wind and the draft of cool air welcomes you as you enter
the southwest tower of the castle. Strong granite stones masoned with excep-
tional skill form the cone that makes up the tower. Tall stairs lead upwards,
each step just below an average human's knee spiral to the top. Along the
tower walls murder holes give a field of observation to that side of the
castle. Green moss grows between the goves of the fine stone. A damp cool
breeze of air blows through the tower. Hanging on the stone wall, visible to
all who look, is a small sign carved from redwood.

5725.title: The Top of the Southwest Tower
5725.description:
The cross winds blow you slighty about on top of the tower. From this height
all around the castle can be more than clearly viewed. A sign carved of red-
wood hangs on one of the walls. Upon another wall is a huge golden plaque
with names engraved upon it. A honeysuckle vine grows along the walls, its
leaves and flowers reaching out over just about every inch of the walls, its
roots dug into the floor beneath the plaque, a few roots reaching upward
and acting as the source of a steady flow of honeysuckle nectar which falls
into a shining golden basin. Amidst the splendor of the flowering vines are
trophies of mage heads, beneath which a great weapon hangs in honor. The
floor is covered with a thick coating of orange moss.

extras.description:
You look upon the walls and see eleven mage heads above eleven great weapons.
Each head looks grotesque, but is otherwise well-preserved. Beneath each head,
and above each weapon, is a name plate. You are given to understand that a
BloodKnight was responsible for the death of each mage.
Beneath the mage head labeled, 'Tauvi', is a scythe-shaped weapon, exotic in
nature. Beneath the mage head labeled , 'Sorin', is a whip that appears well
preserved yet at one time heavily used. Under the head labeled, 'Belgarion'
you see a great sword with a few nicks marring its edges. Beneath the head
labeled, 'Krosis' is a dagger whose blade still carries the blood of the
slain. Under the head labeled, 'Adolaphus', you see a huge polearm, its blade
gleaming in the available light. Under the head labeled, 'Pholos', a great
staff blends in with the vines as though a slim tree trunk belonged there.
The head labeled, 'Margoth' rests above a huge battleaxe, while the head
labeled, 'Dyomsis' rests above a pair of razor gloves symbolizing a monk's
hard-knuckled fists. Beneath the head labeled, 'Ayladriah', is a flail of
huge dimension, and beneath the head labeled, 'Barqu', is a huge mace that
could only be wieded by someone the size of a troll, centaur, or giant.
Lastly, beneath the head labeled, 'Girlal', you see a sharp, sturdy spear.

Looking at one of the stones in the wall, you see
some scratchings, something written in the stone.

5726.title: The Armory
5726.description:
The thick stone stairs lead straight down into this room. The air here seems
a bit more moist and the temperature a bit cooler. Moss seems to thrive on
the smooth stone walls that make up the basement room here. The room slopes
to form a pit for weapons and gear won in battles but not needed. Visible
exits are to the south and the stairs leading upward. The scent of alcohol
wafts in from the south.

5727.title: The Crusader Bar
5727.description:
You enter a cavern with stacks of beer barrels. On the western side a few
large racks hold many bottles of wine in them. A large wooden counter serves
as a bar with many sturdy stools surrounding it. A large minotaur with a
patch over one eye grunts as he fills orders. A large knife board rests on
the southern wall for throwing practice and entertainment. Many more barrels
line the exit to the east.

5728.title: The Crusader Canteen
5728.description:
This is the Crusader Canteen. Behind the thick oak counter stands the giant
shopkeeper. Various goods are stacked in an orderly way on shelves behind the
counter. Crates of all shapes and sizes lie stacked all about. Torches on the
south and north walls provide this room with a dim lighting. An exit lies to
the west, from which direction you smell the scent of alcohol.

5729.title: Foyer to the Altar Room
5729.description:
The Roman arches continue from the Inner Keep, gracefully overlooking this
quiet spot. The granite floor below has been polished to near mirror shine.
Suits of armor decorate the north and south walls, and in between those suits
a colorful shield representing a family which has given several generations
of honorable warriors to the service of the Crusade. They are colorful, but
most are badly dented and one shows signs of scorching. The walls near the
Inner Keep are covered with haphazard blood stains in the shape of human
hands, some overlapping.

5730.title: Altar to Nature
5730.description:
This space further connects to the Green Room. It is barely noticeable where
one room begins and the other ends. Plants, vines, flowers, and vegetation of
all sorts grow plentiful here. A strange wooden altar is built to honor true
nature. A sense of purity with the land is felt while one is near the altar.
On either side of the altar are natural wooden tables, as though they grew as
such, their legs rooted into the ground. Upon those tables are small potted
oak trees, bonsai of great age and beauty. Their leaves are tiny replicas of
full-sized oak leaves, golden in color.
